Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: I hear this sentiment so often from creative entrepreneurs and small business founders

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Entrepreneurs by nature tend to be people who have big dreams and the guts to follow them

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: On the flip side, they often shy away from, look down upon, or downplay the details that go along with execution

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: You can set big, hairy, audacious goals for your company

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Goals are critical

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: You can also determine your core values

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: But without understanding what goes into the execution, you risk tanking your company

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: One concept to use for a framework around execution is the concept of profitability

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: When you think about the profitability of an idea, you need to think about two parts: what goes in and what comes out

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: People, resources, funds, and time go in

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: How big a step you can make toward reaching your goal is what comes out

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Here are three ways for a big picture creative think about profitability

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Money is a way of creating a measurable goal

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Some creative people feel shame about wanting to make money

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Or believe that it shouldn’t be a priority

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Especially if that creative is also a woman

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Not everyone is looking to make $1B

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Some goals align with giving back to a certain community

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Some companies are outright non-profit organizations

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: That’s ok

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: In order for you to further any goal that you have, you are going to need money

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Being fiscally responsible and socially conscious are not mutually exclusive

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: This is the fundamental concept of profit

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: I worked with a nonprofit company last year

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: They had an amazing cause and wanted to put on a huge fundraising event in support of their mission

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: The leaders were well connected in the community

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: They knew they could host a large gala that would bring in quite a bit of money

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: I asked them to put together a budget for the event

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: The number of people they wanted to invite meant they needed an enormous space

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: The cost of the event space erased the amount of money they would raise for the organization

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: So, the revenues would be large, but the profits would not exist

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: We figured out a way to scale back the event

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: The revenues were not as high as if they had hosted a grand affair

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: But more money came back to the organization, which was the goal

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: The moral is, if you have to spend $2 to bring yourself $1 closer to your goal, you better have a great rationale to do it

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Not every opportunity is going to result in profit right away

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: But an idea now can mean more profit down the road

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: It's pretty common for a biotech or pharma product to lose money in the first year it is on the market

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: A lot of money is required to get a sales force up to speed and a marketing campaign right

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: That early investment in a product will pay off massive dividends in years 2–10

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: The revenues from those latter years will more than make up for the early investments

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: So the investment is worthwhile

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Its ok if an idea isn’t profitable right away

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Investing in things like coaching or writing classes don’t have an obvious near-term profit

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: But, have a well-informed opinion on the timeline

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: And how much money you might need to invest until you reach that point

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: Profit is only one way to think about executing on your goals and your vision

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: But it is a framework

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: It makes you think about a few of the puzzle pieces that need to fit together to create the bigger picture

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: And those little pieces might not be as dramatic or fun as the big dreams

Author: Deb Knobelman, PhD
Text: But without them, execution becomes nearly impossible

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: What drives you crazy? What can you just not understand? Why is something the way that it is? Why isn’t it better?

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Ask yourself these questions to identify the problem you are going to solve when starting a business

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: For us, it was the complexity and time in the food delivery service market

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Each time we ordered food, it was a painstakingly long process, so we decided to fix it

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Entrepreneur Peter Rahal wanted pro-paleo food and snacks after his CrossFit workouts

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: But, there were none

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: So, he decided to make his own

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Five years later, his company RXBAR was sold to Kellogg’s for $600 million

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: To find an idea, find something that pains you

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Find Something That Pains You

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Finding something that bothers you is a great start, but if it does not bother other people as well, then you don’t exactly have a business

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Just because I don’t like when people pronounce it “Chipolte” rather than “Chipotle” does not mean everybody else feels the same!

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: My friends and I created a 5-question mini-survey and distributed it to the 75 students in our business program, asking about average order time and overall delivery experience satisfaction

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: We learned that we were not the only ones who wanted something more out of food delivery

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Navy Seal Randy Hetrick became bored of his mundane routine while he was deployed, he threw a jujitsu belt over a door and started doing pull-ups

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: He thought it was great, but did other exercisers without access to a gym have the same problem? Randy showed the idea to his Seal team and then other Seal members around the world, and pretty soon he created TRX bands, a $50 million fitness company

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Make sure your personal pain is shared by other people

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Make Sure It Also Pains Other People

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: I was fortunate enough to have already been doing some work with a startup founder a few years older in the food delivery space

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: I told him that I would continue to work with him for free if he would help us get our endeavor off the ground

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: He agreed, and I can honestly say we would not have known the nitty gritty details of starting a business without him

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Michael Bloomberg bumped into a guy when he interviewed to become a trader at a firm called Salomon Brothers & Hutzler

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: The man he bumped into was William R

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Salomon, and Bloomberg attributes his success to the way this man led by example and guided him through the process of becoming a businessman and an even better human being

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Bloomberg used this wisdom to create one of the largest companies and become one of the wealthiest men on the planet

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Even Bloomberg needed to find a guide

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Make sure you do the same

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Find The Right Guide

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: With our food delivery company, we made an absurdly simple email campaign with 30 emails we had from our classmates

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Our MVP was a one-option food delivery service where we told you exactly what we were making with a detailed ingredients list and nutritional information, and the only choice the consumer had to make was “meal” or “no meal

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: ” We gathered enough ingredients for the people who replied, “meal” to the email, and I cooked 20 meals for our first order

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: We charged people on Venmo and then asked for feedback

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: This dropped average order time to about one minute rather than the 27 it took us that Sunday

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: When Alli Webb took a few handfuls of supplies over to her friends’ house and started blow-drying their hair, she became better and better at it

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Soon these simple and enjoyable interactions and experiences testing her concept grew into a $70 million company known as DryBar

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Start small

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Build fast

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: And test to see if your MVP gains traction

Author: Jordan “J” Gross
Text: Test a Minimum Viable Product (MVP)

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: I’ve talked about the stated reasons VCs give for passing: those that have to do with the market, founders, individual VC or firm, fundraising process, product or technology, and business model or go-to-market

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: But sometimes actions (or inactions) speak louder than words

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: If a VC goes silent on you at any point in the fundraising process, they’re not that interested

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: It’s poor form and you deserve a reason, but overflowing inboxes, portfolio company emergencies, and unwieldy and unpredictable schedules are the norm in our jobs

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: VCs will lose interest

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: Speed kills in venture, so as a founder you should work to create and maintain momentum

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: In the spirit of transparency, the two most common reasons why I pass are first, not feeling strongly about the founders, and second, a lack of personal interest in or conviction about in the space

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: I’ve seen how hard it is to build a successful venture-scale company

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: It’s riddled with adversity

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: Pivots and crises are the norm

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: If I don’t have a real connection with the founders in a space that they are mission-driven to care about immensely, it’s a pass

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: Success takes a rare combination of exceptional people, timing, and technology

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: It’s a long, drawn-out battle, and VCs will crawl over broken glass for the founders we’ve chosen to back

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: Having conviction in either of these two components (or ideally both) will overcome almost any other reason for passing

Author: Sarah A. Downey
Text: VCs make exceptions for people and ideas that we think are truly exceptional

Author: Dave Schools
Text: When you enjoy digital marketing more than the thing you’re actually selling, you’re free to be emotionally detached, allowing you to sell literally anything

Author: Dave Schools
Text: That’s exactly what happened with Jackson Cunningham

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He searched for a product that would sell, not one for which he had any personal affinity

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Very methodically, he plugged in keywords, analyzed online traffic, and assessed the current market offering for hundreds of products

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He found an overlooked corner of the fashion sector that hadn’t been penetrated with a premium, high-quality, and high-priced option

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He found authentic Italian artists who designed gorgeous masks and signed them

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He invested his own money to source inventory

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He spun up a Shopify store in the Spring and called the brand VIVO Masks

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Juggling this new project with his real estate business became untenable

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He couldn’t do both

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Searching on the popular freelancing site Upwork, he found a local professional to take over his real estate work

Author: Dave Schools
Text: But the person he met was not who he expected

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He met Josh for coffee at a local shop and they hit it off

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Turns out, they read the same books and listened to the same podcasts

Author: Dave Schools
Text: When Jackson mentioned the masks project, Josh was intrigued

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The meeting was no longer a freelance interview

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “Would you be interested in going in on VIVO Masks with me, fifty-fifty?” asked Jackson

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Josh nodded enthusiastically

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Unbeknownst to the duo at the time, this coffee meeting put the roots in the ground for a lifelong multi-business partnership

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Their skill sets were and still are complementary, says Jackson: Jackson is more operational and passionate about automation

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Josh is more strategic and adds a long-term mindset to their overall marketing plan

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Together, they manage a stable of contractors (more on how this exactly works soon)

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “Having two of us helps smooth the inevitable highs and lows in motivation that come from running a business,” says Jackson

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “When I’m down, he’s up, and when he’s down, I’m up — we keep each other balanced and focused

Author: Dave Schools
Text: By October of the same year, the cofounders grew VIVO Masks to $30,000 a month in sales by October

Author: Dave Schools
Text: They didn’t pay themselves a dime, but rather reinvested the revenue into growing inventory and marketing until they fully stopped the real estate business in the following Spring

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The key to setting up an effective digital marketing funnel has nothing to do with tweaking online advertisement settings, copy, and the perfect software setup to form a “well-oiled machine” where every $1 spent nets $1

Author: Dave Schools
Text: 50 in revenue, says Jackson

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “It’s much more human than that, especially at the beginning

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Jackson says spend most of your time finding the absolute best possible product first

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “If you put most of your effort into sourcing the best possible product on the front end, it will make your marketing down the road much easier,” he says

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He spoke about how his handmade masks have high-end artisanal Italian origins

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “I can say with full integrity that I sell the highest-quality masquerade masks in the world

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Once you’ve found a “really nice” product to sell online, shift your thinking from short-term — “How do I get this to make money next month? — to long-term — “How do I get this to make money next year?”

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “There are a hundred options to create money next month but not so many options to create money next year,” says Jackson

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “When you start to think more long-term, the possible growth strategies shrink down

Author: Dave Schools
Text: It’s a much clearer way to think through growth options

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He likens this way of thinking about marketing as “planting seeds” where you don’t reap the rewards quickly and the initiatives are a slower burn, such as partnerships, content pieces, and service enhancements like free shipping, but turn out to be more profitable and sustainable in the end

Author: Dave Schools
Text: This Bezosian approach to growth has proven successful time after time, not only in business, but also in life

Author: Dave Schools
Text: In his book, 12 Rules For Life, bestselling author Jordan B

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Peterson’s puts it most succinctly in Rule #7: “Pursue what is meaningful, not what is expedient

Author: Dave Schools
Text: For products, this means making it the highest quality product possible and not cutting corners, cheapening, or holding back anything that would stop your product from being the best possible version of itself

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Quality is meaningful, not expedient

Author: Dave Schools
Text: For services, follow what the author of The 48 Laws of Power, Robert Greene, writes as the Fifth Law of Power: guard your reputation far above anything else

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Compromising your character may win the deal, appease yourself, or fatten the contract in the short-term, but once it’s ruined can never be regained again

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Think of how icons like Bill Cosby, Harvey Weinstein, and Kevin Spacey have been ruined by certain choices

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Reputation comes from what is meaningful, not expedient

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Jackson explains how this principle applies to an e-commerce company:

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “You can spin up ads when you’re ready to scale,” he mentioned as an example of a strategy to hit short-term targets

Author: Dave Schools
Text: But ads disappear as soon as you stop paying for them

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Whereas a well-written evergreen content piece, for example, can continue to provide value for years on end

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Jackson points at venture-backed companies and summer project upstarts that aim to be successful as quickly as possible but are actually hindering their own growth by aiming at short-term targets

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “Three years is the way to be thinking,” he says

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Give the seeds some time to grow

Author: Dave Schools
Text: It’s similar to working out in the gym

Author: Dave Schools
Text: You won’t see immediate rewards, but with time you’ll start to see results

Author: Dave Schools
Text: If you can think in this longterm mindset, “It’s very freeing,” Jackson says

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Less than a year later in 2012, VIVO Masks hit a ceiling in sales

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Jackson and Josh tried lots of things to continue the brand’s growth, such as adding fascinators to the site, but nothing moved the needle

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Nevertheless, the business was a steady cash calf (a small cash cow) and the cofounders looked at each other and said, “Let’s make twenty of these things

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Using a stack of keyword research, landing pages, and ad traffic data, Jackson began testing and validating all manner of products, from Japanese kimonos to wigs to dream catchers to top hats

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Choosing the right product to focus on was not black and white

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Even worse, most of them could sell — top hats sold pretty well — but each product required an equal amount of work

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The more stores they opened, the more work it would become

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The idea of 20 online stores soon became unfeasible

Author: Dave Schools
Text: During this process of validating various product ideas, Jackson learned a valuable lesson about how to choose a product

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “Validating is overused,” he says

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “What am I really validating — the fact that something will sell online? That’s not the hard part

Author: Dave Schools
Text: I can definitely sell wigs online

Author: Dave Schools
Text: [The purpose of the validation period] is more like you’re giving yourself a confidence boost that will get you through the months to come when you’re selling barely anything

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Jackson and Josh eventually landed on their second product: suspenders

Author: Dave Schools
Text: They researched the suspenders market and found that 90% of the products were low-quality, mass-produced, or old-school grandpa ‘spenders that were too thick

Author: Dave Schools
Text: So they set out to design their own and aimed at making them the best product in the market

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Similar to sourcing the masks from Italy, they sourced their suspenders materials and fabrics from the highest quality makers they could find — in England

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Soon they were manufacturing their own brand of suspenders at the level of quality they knew they could build a business with

Author: Dave Schools
Text: This is a serious concern for early founders and has led to hellacious lawsuits for many

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Jackson’s response to this concern was unflinching

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He says:

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “Anybody can make anything nowadays,” he says

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “Often there’s not a lot you can do to protect your products from copycats, but the reality is that there are built-in and somewhat painful barriers to entry, like hefty startup and inventory costs, lower margins, and no first-mover advantage

Author: Dave Schools
Text: As JJ Suspenders grew bigger, it reached a healthy sales mark, and yet, similar to VIVO Masks, it leveled off and led to diminishing returns

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Back to the drawing board but this time with more cash, Jackson wanted to give his girlfriend, who worked at a nonprofit, the same freedom he had as a digital entrepreneur

Author: Dave Schools
Text: She should start a company so they could travel together, he reasoned

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “What are you interested in?” he asked her

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “Cats,” she said

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Jackson typed “cats” into a search engine

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Cat memes, cat photos, cat costumes — all the things you would expect — showed up at the top of the search results

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Except one keyword phrase stuck out

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Cat tree

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “What the hell is a cat tree?” Jackson wondered

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He applied the same filter that landed him in masquerade masks and men’s suspenders: “Could I make a better product than what’s out there?”

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Turns out cat furniture is a lazy industry that hasn’t experienced innovation for hundreds of years, he says

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Five days later in 2016, Jackson embarked on his most capital intensive e-commerce project yet, entering the $70 billion pet industry (USA)

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He hired a product engineer, a product designer, and a cat behavioralist to take an Elon Muskian “First Principles Thinking” approach to solving the most fundamental problems in a cat’s life

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “I get to solve interesting problems,” he says

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Although he isn’t sure if he would be doing this if it was his first e-commerce company

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “I’m going to be losing money for a few years

Author: Dave Schools
Text: You can view the high-end cat furniture he is designing and manufacturing at the company’s website: www

Author: Dave Schools
Text: tuftandpaw

Author: Dave Schools
Text: com

Author: Dave Schools
Text: How it started: (M)ask me anything

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Masquerade masks

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The only 3-step e-commerce growth funnel you’ll ever need

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Don’t think about making money next month

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “Let’s make twenty of these things

Author: Dave Schools
Text: How to choose a startup idea when you have a ton of ideas

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Physical products without patents are in danger of being knocked off by foreign factories

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The biggest business of them all

Author: Dave Schools
Text: One of the first rules of marketing is:

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Running three businesses sounds like it would be the antithesis to staying focused on one thing

Author: Dave Schools
Text: But Jackson Cunningham says he spends only one hour a week managing VIVO Masks and JJ Suspenders and pours the rest of his time and efforts into Tuft+Paw

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Here’s how

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Jackson’s process and favorite tools for automation look like this:

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Jackson knows what it’s like to feel distracted, to be ‘busy’ doing too much, and not making any real progress

Author: Dave Schools
Text: A lot of fires need to be put out when you have three businesses on your plate

Author: Dave Schools
Text: If you’re overwhelmed and frazzled — burned out from being too busy — you’re thinking too small, says Jackson

Author: Dave Schools
Text: This is how Jackson and Josh felt when they were running five projects simultaneously

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Every day they worked on hundreds of emails and tasks but didn’t get anything done

Author: Dave Schools
Text: If you’re spinning your wheels like this, it’s a sign you need to pick something bigger to sink your teeth into, the founder recommends

Author: Dave Schools
Text: This is how he feels about Tuft+Paw today

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “There’s so much I can do in this one area,” he says

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “I found a thing with lots of potential that I can call ‘my baby

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Having a bunch of things on your plate is totally fine, says Jackson, as long as you can keep your focus

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The key to focus is to be fully immersed in something so that it doesn’t feel like you’re working

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The challenge for entrepreneurs is to find that something that’s big enough, rewarding enough, and interesting enough

Author: Dave Schools
Text: For Jackson, the vision is so clear with Tuft+Paw that he has to stop himself from working almost every day because he loves it so much

Author: Dave Schools
Text: “I’m passionately against ugly cat furniture,” he smiles

Author: Dave Schools
Text: How he spends one hour a week on two businesses and devotes the rest of his time to the third

Author: Dave Schools
Text: 6 hiring tips for Upwork:

Author: Dave Schools
Text: If you’re a founder who’s feeling frazzled and unfocused…

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Key takeaways to remember:

Author: Dave Schools
Text: This man, who shall remain nameless, keeps a very low profile

Author: Dave Schools
Text: I happen to run into him and strike up a conversation, which led to another conversation over lunch

Author: Dave Schools
Text: We sat down at an organic food market for lunch and he began to tell me his story

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He was a writer and senior lead auditor of the ISO 9000

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The ISO 9000 is a globally-adopted, quality business management standard used by huge brands with support businesses located internationally

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The reason why it exists is so stakeholders can believe with confidence that a manufacturing plant located in another country will produce exactly what the contract says, without having to travel to that plant to conduct a huge inspection

Author: Dave Schools
Text: If the plant is ISO 9000- or ISO 9001-certified, then they know it will perform to standard

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The ISO 9000 is based on 7 quality management principles

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Adherers include companies in the automotive, chemical, and aerospace manufacturing industries such as GM, Chrysler, Boeing, General Electric, Northrop Grumman, Alibaba, and Eastman Chemical Company

Author: Dave Schools
Text: This man told me that he applied the quality management principles he helped establish in the ISO 9000 to the ten separate businesses he operates today

Author: Dave Schools
Text: His businesses include a skateboard and BMX shop, a network of pawnshops, a consulting practice, a musical instruments shop, an Internet sales business, a real estate development and management firm, a firearms shop, a marine products online store, a standup paddleboards shop, and a visual displays store

Author: Dave Schools
Text: You would think these ten companies would dominate his time

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Not so

Author: Dave Schools
Text: He spends his time sailing around the world with his wife and family in one of his sailboats, the “Zephyr” or the “Whispering Eye

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Here’s what he told me about life and business

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Visualize everything below in quotes

Author: Dave Schools
Text: If you were to look at just one of the ten businesses I have, it would not be that impressive

Author: Dave Schools
Text: It would provide for a simple, decent living for a small family, not much more than that

Author: Dave Schools
Text: It’s an unglamorous yet stable, small and focused, profitable operation

Author: Dave Schools
Text: By itself, it’s basic and ordinary

Author: Dave Schools
Text: You young, startup-crazy whippersnappers want something so high-profile and instantly viral

Author: Dave Schools
Text: My businesses aren’t viral, but they help a specific type of person by providing a quality solution, over and over again

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Multiply a small, quaint, and profitable business by ten and you’ve got a diversified, multi-million dollar portfolio

Author: Dave Schools
Text: If you can help it, do not partner with anyone

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The more partners you have, the more you have to split the pie

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The more partners you have, the more you have to fight for your point of view

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The more partners you have, the more time it will take to execute anything

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Co-founding is overrated

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Learn the skills yourself, bootstrap, and then hire the right people (see below)

Author: Dave Schools
Text: We are in a small market

Author: Dave Schools
Text: We are not in San Francisco, Paris, or New York

Author: Dave Schools
Text: I’ve seen that smaller markets are two to three years behind the larger markets; whatever is selling in the big cities, will not be selling in ours at the same time

Author: Dave Schools
Text: But give it two to three years and it will be selling like hotcakes

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Find out what this is, and be the first to open a shop in your small market

Author: Dave Schools
Text: My employees are transferable between business lines

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Each employee is multi-skilled

Author: Dave Schools
Text: The girl behind the counter is doing social media marketing online in between customers checking out

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Each business has a manager with a bank card

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Each manager is trained in the same principles of the ISO 9000 and is given full control of their business

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Through a tight incentive plan, I make sure that if the business does well, they do well

Author: Dave Schools
Text: If they want to order the hottest, new products to sell in their shop, they have to sell enough to fill up the bank account, to purchase the inventory

Author: Dave Schools
Text: I look for people who are independent and responsible, who take complete ownership of their business

Author: Dave Schools
Text: This allows me to travel the way I do, because I know my employees are working hard for themselves

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Oh, and we have parties OFTEN

Author: Dave Schools
Text: We casually share ideas about what marketing tactics are working in one business that may work in another, we have performance awards, and we do fun things together

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Here is the mission statement for all of my companies, it’s very simple:

Author: Dave Schools
Text: To be successful in business does not mean changing the world

Author: Dave Schools
Text: It means meeting a need (regardless of size) well and dependably over time

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Sell something

Author: Dave Schools
Text: If it’s a product, make sure its quality, then sell it at a fair price, and make sure the breakeven point is doable for you as the business owner

Author: Dave Schools
Text: If it’s a service, make sure there is added value, as in you are very good and knowledgeable in your field, and the service provided is unique, at least in your market

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Multiple Revenue Streams

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Do Not Partner

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Study the Market

Author: Dave Schools
Text: Be Very, Very Careful With Who You Hire

Author: Dave Schools
Text: How to Do Well in Business
